xxl.util
Class Math

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.util.Math
public class Math
extends Object

The class Math contains methods with regard to extend the basic numeric operations of java.lang.Math.

See Also:
Comparator, ComparableComparator

Method Detail

ceil

public static final int ceil(int i,
                             int base)
Returns the smallest (closest to negative infinity) value that is not less than the first argument and is equal to a mathematical integer.
This value is computed with the help of the second argument base as follows:
 	return i + i%base==0 ? 0 : base-i%base;
Parameters:
i - each element returned is greater than this value.
base - the rest added to the first argument.
Returns:
an interger value that is not less than the first argument, computed by i + i%base==0 ? 0 : base-i%base.

floor

public static final int floor(int i,
                              int base)
Returns the largest (closest to positive infinity) value that is not greater than the first argument and is equal to a mathematical integer.
This value is computed with the help of the second argument base as follows:
 	return i - i%base;
Parameters:
i - each element returned is not greater than this value.
base - the rest subtracted from the first argument.
Returns:
an intger value that is not greater than the first argument, computed by i - i%base.

signum

public static final int signum(double d)
An implementation of the signum function for double values.
This function returns:
  • '1' if the given argument is greater than '0'.
  • '0' if the given argument is equal to '0'.
  • '-1' if the given argument is less than '0'.
Parameters:
d - the argument to be tested.
Returns:
'1' if the given argument is greater than '0', '0' if it is equal to it, else '-1'.

signum

public static final int signum(long i)
An implementation of the signum function for long values. This function returns:
  • '1' if the given argument is greater than '0'.
  • '0' if the given argument is equal to '0'.
  • '-1' if the given argument is less than '0'.
Parameters:
i - the argument to be tested.
Returns:
'1' if the given argument is greater than '0', '0' if it is equal to it, else '-1'.

medianOfThree

public static final Object medianOfThree(Object a,
                                         Object b,
                                         Object c,
                                         Comparator comparator)
Returns the median of three given objects using the given comparator.
These objects must not be different by pairs. The implementation is as follows: 
 
 	if (comparator.compare(a,b) <= 0)
 		if (comparator.compare(b,c) <= 0)
 			return b;
 		else					//i.e. c<b
 			return Comparators.max(a,c,comparator);
 	else						//i.e. b<a
 		if (comparator.compare(a,c) <= 0)
 			return a;
 		else					//i.e. c<a
 			return Comparators.max(b,c,comparator);
Parameters:
a - the first object.
b - the second object.
c - the third object.
comparator - the comparator used to compare each tuple of objects.
Returns:
the median of the three given objects concerning the given comparator.

medianOfThree

public static final Object medianOfThree(Object[] array,
                                         Comparator comparator)
The 3-median-strategy used to compute the pivot element in the Quicksort-algorithm.
Three objects are taken from the given object-array, namely the left one, the right one and one of the middle. For these three elements the median is computed using the given comparator with the intention that the median delivers a separation in nearly equal parts.
Parameters:
array - the object which delivers the left, middle and right element.
comparator - the comparator used to compare each tuple of the taken objects.
Returns:
the median of the three given objects concerning the given comparator.

doubleToNormalizedLongBits

public static long doubleToNormalizedLongBits(double d)
Extracts the mantisse-bits of a double-value.
Precondition: d in [0;1) (i.e. 1.0 excluded).

We use full precision: i.e. bit 10^-1 is at position 62, 10^-2 at position 61 and so on. (We do not use bit 63 because bit 63 is interpreted as the sign of a long, i.e. the result of long-comparisons would not be correct.)
There is no need to store the exponent (=10^-1) or sign (+).

Note, that the maximum precision of doubles is then restricted to 2^-63=1.08*10^-19.
This method is extremly useful to create z-codes and to compute replicate-rectangles. The bit-fields can be easily merged to a zCode.

Parameters:
d - the double the mantisse-bits should be extracted of.
Returns:
a normalized long bit representation of the given double value.
See Also:
xxl.spatial

normalizedLongBitsToDouble

public static double normalizedLongBitsToDouble(long l)
Complementary function to doubleToNormalizedLongBits(double d).
Parameters:
l - a long that will be interpreted as a normalized long bit representation of a double value.
the - double value belonging to the given normalized long bit representation.
See Also:
doubleToNormalizedLongBits(double)

zCode

public static BitSet zCode(long[] bitField,
                           int componentPrecision)
Computes the z-code of the given bit field, bitField, by merging the the bit-field-longs and returns it as a BitSet.
The BitSet's precision is set to:
 	componentPrecision*bitField.length
So the basic used precision is the array's component precision.
Parameters:
bitField - a long array the z-code should be computed of.
componentPrecision - the bitField's component precision.
Returns:
a BitSet representing the z-code of the given bitField.
See Also:
BitSet.BitSet(int), zCode(long[], int, int)

zCode2

public static BitSet zCode2(long[] bitField,
                            int precision)
Computes the z-code of the given bit field, bitField, by merging the bit-field-longs and returns it as a BitSet.
(EXPERIMENTAL)
Parameters:
bitField - a long array the z-code should be computed of.
precision - the returned BitSet's full precision.
additionalBits - added bits, that should be taken into consideration too, i.e. the precision of the BitSet is incremented by this value.
Returns:
a BitSet representing the z-code of the given bitField.
See Also:
BitSet.BitSet(int), zCode(long[], int, int)

zCode

public static BitSet zCode(long[] bitField,
                           int componentPrecision,
                           int additionalBits)
Computes the z-code of the given bit field, bitField, by merging the bit-field-longs and returns it as a BitSet.
The BitSet's precision is set to:
 	componentPrecision*bitField.length+additionalBits
So the basic used precision is the array's component precision, but it can be increased by adding additionalBits.
Parameters:
bitField - a long array the z-code should be computed of.
componentPrecision - the bitField's component precision.
additionalBits - added bits, that should be taken into consideration too, i.e. the precision of the BitSet is incremented by this value.
Returns:
a BitSet representing the z-code of the given bitField.
See Also:
BitSet.BitSet(int)
